intro: Castilleja pilosa var. inverta, commonly known as the hairy leaf Indian paintbrush, is a hemiparasitic plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Orobanchaceae family and relies on other plants for some of its nutrients through specialized root structures called haustoria. The plant is characterized by its showy, red-orange flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are hairy and alternate, and it typically grows in open, sunny habitats such as grasslands and woodlands. Castilleja pilosa var. inverta plays an important role in pollination and serves as a food source for various insects and animals.
